comment_text: Other than the fact that it has a better sound, I believe that there is no, and there was no, reason to have it in the pledge.  It was added during the communist scare, simply because of hysteria at the time.  While the majority of the US are Christian, we are NOT a Christian nation, and our founders set it up that way on purpose.  The personal religious beliefs of the ones who are writing the laws should not be included in those laws. In fact, it is stated in the 1st Amendment that it can't be.
argument_text: Under God  is part of American tradition and history

comment_text: The words 'under God' were added at the height of the McCarthy era, and, given the constitutional requirement of the separation of Church and State, do not belong in the Pledge of Allegiance. Regardless of one's personal beliefs, the Constitution is the one document all Americans return to, and 'under God' is not part of that.
This country was founded under God and should stay under God.

'God' is not an irrefutable fact; it is a personal belief, a byproduct of religion which this country was founded on the freedom of, for, or none at all.  There is no proof of gods existence and religion and state MUST be separate in order for all US citizens to be included. Taking the phrase out would do absolutely no harm to any religion or practicing religious people in this country, but it would include every citizen without anyone or any belief system being disregarded, disrespected or left out.  That is why i feel it must be omitted from the pledge.
argument_text: Removing under god would promote religious tolerance

comment_text: Shouldn't it be a pledge that ALL U.S. citizens are comfortable saying?  Doesn't the pledge appear flawed and leave a bitter taste in the mouths of Atheists?  Would it be all that different if it said under a Protestant God? A pledge should unite not alienate it's people.
